metadata.subject: chemistry
metadata.dotPoint: Molecular, structural and semi-structural (condensed) formulas and skeletal structures of alkanes (including cyclohexane), alkenes, benzene, haloalkanes, primary amines, primary amides, alcohols (primary, secondary and tertiary), aldehydes, ketones, carboxylic acids and non-branched esters

molecular_formula_definition.name: Molecular Formula Definition
molecular_formula_definition.description: A molecular formula shows the types and numbers of atoms in a molecule
molecular_formula_definition.correct: The molecular formula lists elements and atom counts, with C first, then H, then other elements alphabetically. It gives total atoms but does not show bonding arrangement.

shows bonding arrangement.error: Molecular formulas do not show how atoms are connected.
shows bonding arrangement.fix: Molecular formula = atom count only. Structural formula = bonding arrangement.
shows bonding arrangement.action: Write the molecular formula for ethanol (C₂H₆O). Note it tells you nothing about which atoms bond to which.

distinguishes between isomers.error: Molecular formulas cannot distinguish between isomers.
distinguishes between isomers.fix: Isomers have identical molecular formulas but different structures. You need structural formulas to tell them apart.
distinguishes between isomers.action: Both ethanol and dimethyl ether have molecular formula C₂H₆O. Draw both structures to see the difference.

lists hydrogen first.error: Carbon always comes first in molecular formulas of organic compounds.
lists hydrogen first.fix: Convention: C first, then H, then remaining elements alphabetically.
lists hydrogen first.action: Practice writing: propan-1-ol is C₃H₈O, not H₈C₃O or OC₃H₈.

persistent.gap: You are confusing what molecular formulas can and cannot show.
persistent.action: Write the molecular formula for three isomers of C₄H₁₀O. All have the same formula, different structures.

structural_formula_definition.name: Structural Formula Definition
structural_formula_definition.description: A structural formula shows all atoms and all bonds explicitly
structural_formula_definition.correct: The structural formula shows every atom with its chemical symbol and represents all covalent bonds as lines (single line for single bond, double line for double bond).

omits hydrogen atoms.error: Structural formulas show ALL atoms including every hydrogen.
omits hydrogen atoms.fix: Every hydrogen bonded to carbon is drawn explicitly in a structural formula. This is what makes it detailed but tedious for large molecules.
omits hydrogen atoms.action: Draw the complete structural formula of propane showing all 3 C and all 8 H atoms with lines.

uses zigzag lines.error: Zigzag representation is for skeletal formulas, not structural formulas.
uses zigzag lines.fix: Structural formulas draw each atom symbol explicitly. Skeletal formulas use zigzags and omit C and H.
uses zigzag lines.action: Compare: structural formula has every C and H written out; skeletal has only zigzag lines.

condenses repeating units.error: Condensing is for semi-structural formulas, not full structural formulas.
condenses repeating units.fix: Structural formulas show every single bond. Semi-structural formulas condense CH₂ groups in brackets.
condenses repeating units.action: Structural: H-C-C-C-C-H with all bonds. Semi-structural: CH₃CH₂CH₂CH₃ or CH₃(CH₂)₂CH₃.

persistent.gap: You are confusing structural formulas with other representation types.
persistent.action: Draw propane in all four formats: molecular, structural, semi-structural, and skeletal. Note what each shows and hides.

semi_structural_formula.name: Semi-Structural (Condensed) Formula
semi_structural_formula.description: Semi-structural formulas show atom groupings but usually omit bonds
semi_structural_formula.correct: Semi-structural formulas group atoms (like CH₃, CH₂, OH) and usually omit bond lines. Brackets condense repeating units or highlight branches.

shows all individual bonds.error: Semi-structural formulas typically omit bonds between atoms.
shows all individual bonds.fix: The formula CH₃CH₂OH is semi-structural because bonds are implied, not drawn. Compare to H-C-C-O-H with all bonds.
shows all individual bonds.action: Write CH₃CH₂CH₂OH. The bonds between atoms are understood, not drawn.

always uses brackets.error: Brackets are optional in semi-structural formulas.
always uses brackets.fix: CH₃CH₂CH₂CH₃ and CH₃(CH₂)₂CH₃ are both valid semi-structural formulas for butane.
always uses brackets.action: Practice writing heptane: CH₃CH₂CH₂CH₂CH₂CH₂CH₃ or CH₃(CH₂)₅CH₃ - both correct.

never shows double bonds.error: Double bonds should be shown in semi-structural formulas.
never shows double bonds.fix: Write CH₂=CH₂ for ethene to show the double bond, or CH₃CH=CH₂ for propene.
never shows double bonds.action: The double bond is important information. Include it: CH₂=CHCH₃ for propene.

persistent.gap: You do not understand how semi-structural formulas balance detail and simplicity.
persistent.action: Convert pentane to semi-structural both ways: fully expanded and using (CH₂) brackets.

bracket_usage.name: Bracket Usage in Semi-Structural Formulas
bracket_usage.description: Brackets serve two purposes: condensing repeating units and highlighting branches
bracket_usage.correct: Brackets condense repeating CH₂ units (like (CH₂)₅) and distinguish branches from the main chain (like CH₃CH(CH₃)CH₃ for 2-methylpropane).

only for condensing repeats.fix: CH₃CH(CH₃)CH₂CH₃ uses brackets to show the methyl branch, not repeating units.
only for condensing repeats.action: Draw 2-methylbutane. The (CH₃) in brackets is a branch, not a repeated unit.

are required for all formulas.error: Brackets are optional; unbracketed formulas are often valid.
are required for all formulas.fix: CH₃CH₂CH₂CH₃ and CH₃(CH₂)₂CH₃ are both correct for butane.
are required for all formulas.action: Write hexane without brackets: CH₃CH₂CH₂CH₂CH₂CH₃ - this is perfectly correct.

place branches after the carbon.error: Branches in brackets appear directly after the carbon they attach to.
place branches after the carbon.fix: For 3-methylpentane: CH₃CH₂CH(CH₃)CH₂CH₃. The (CH₃) follows the C it branches from.
place branches after the carbon.action: Locate the branching carbon first, then place the bracket immediately after.

persistent.gap: You are confused about when and how to use brackets.
persistent.action: Write 2,3-dimethylbutane and 2-methylpentane using correct bracket placement.

skeletal_formula_conventions.name: Skeletal Formula Conventions
skeletal_formula_conventions.description: Skeletal formulas use zigzag lines for the carbon backbone
skeletal_formula_conventions.correct: Skeletal formulas represent hydrocarbon chains as zigzag lines. Each vertex and endpoint represents a carbon atom. C and H symbols are usually omitted, but all other elements are shown.

vertices represent bonds.error: Vertices represent carbon atoms, not bonds.
vertices represent bonds.fix: Each 'corner' or 'point' in the zigzag is a carbon atom. Lines between them are bonds.
vertices represent bonds.action: Count vertices in a skeletal formula. A zigzag with 4 corners = 4 carbon atoms.

hydrogen is always shown.error: Hydrogen bonded to carbon is typically not shown in skeletal formulas.
hydrogen is always shown.fix: Carbons are assumed to have enough H to satisfy four bonds. Only show H bonded to O, N, etc.
hydrogen is always shown.action: In -OH group, the H is shown. In a CH₃ group, hydrogens are implied.

straight lines are standard.error: Zigzag lines are the convention, not straight lines.
straight lines are standard.fix: The zigzag pattern represents the tetrahedral geometry around sp³ carbons.
straight lines are standard.action: Draw hexane as a zigzag with 6 vertices (counting endpoints).

persistent.gap: You do not understand how to read and draw skeletal formulas.
persistent.action: Practice: draw butane, pentane, hexane in skeletal form. Count vertices to verify carbon count.

skeletal_carbon_counting.name: Counting Carbons in Skeletal Formulas
skeletal_carbon_counting.description: Carbon atoms appear at endpoints and vertices of skeletal formulas
skeletal_carbon_counting.correct: Every endpoint (end of a line) and every vertex (where lines meet or change direction) represents a carbon atom. Count all endpoints plus all vertices.

only vertices are carbons.fix: A simple zigzag line has carbons at both ends AND at each bend. Don't forget the end carbons.
only vertices are carbons.action: Draw propane: two bends (1 vertex in middle) plus 2 endpoints = 3 carbons total.

branches don't count.error: Branch endpoints are also carbon atoms.
branches don't count.fix: Every line endpoint, including branches, represents a carbon. A methyl branch adds 1 C.
branches don't count.action: In 2-methylpropane, count the main chain carbons AND the branch endpoint.

double bonds add extra carbons.error: Double bonds do not add carbons; they connect existing carbons.
double bonds add extra carbons.fix: A double bond is still just two carbons connected. The double line shows bond type, not extra atoms.
double bonds add extra carbons.action: Ethene: one double line = 2 carbons connected by a double bond, not 4 carbons.

persistent.gap: You are miscounting carbons in skeletal formulas.
persistent.action: Draw 5 different molecules in skeletal form and practice counting carbons at vertices AND endpoints.

skeletal_heteroatoms.name: Heteroatoms in Skeletal Formulas
skeletal_heteroatoms.description: Atoms other than C must be shown with their chemical symbols
skeletal_heteroatoms.correct: All elements except C (and H bonded to C) must be explicitly written in skeletal formulas. This includes O, N, S, Cl, Br, and others.

oxygen is implied like carbon.error: Oxygen must always be shown explicitly in skeletal formulas.
oxygen is implied like carbon.fix: Write O for alcohols, aldehydes, ketones, etc. Only carbon is hidden.
oxygen is implied like carbon.action: Draw ethanol in skeletal form: zigzag ending in -OH. The O must be visible.

all atoms are hidden.error: Only C and H (bonded to C) are hidden. All other atoms are shown.
all atoms are hidden.fix: For chloromethane: show the Cl symbol. For methylamine: show the NH₂.
all atoms are hidden.action: Practice: draw 1-chloropropane showing the Cl at the end of the chain.

hydrogen on heteroatoms is hidden.error: Hydrogen bonded to O, N, or other heteroatoms must be shown.
hydrogen on heteroatoms is hidden.fix: Write -OH not just -O for alcohols. Write -NH₂ not just -N for amines.
hydrogen on heteroatoms is hidden.action: Compare: C with H hidden vs O with H shown. The difference is what the H bonds to.

persistent.gap: You are incorrectly hiding atoms that should be visible in skeletal formulas.
persistent.action: Draw ethanol, propylamine, and 1-bromobutane in skeletal form, ensuring all heteroatoms are visible.

alkane_structures.name: Alkane Structures
alkane_structures.description: Alkanes contain only C-C single bonds and have formula CₙH₂ₙ₊₂
alkane_structures.correct: Alkanes are saturated hydrocarbons with only single bonds. Their molecular formula follows CₙH₂ₙ₊₂. Structural formulas show all C-C and C-H bonds.

can contain double bonds.error: Alkanes contain only single bonds. Double bonds make alkenes.
can contain double bonds.fix: Alk-ANE = single bonds only. Alk-ENE = contains a C=C double bond.
can contain double bonds.action: Methane, ethane, propane, butane - all have -ane ending, all single bonds only.

formula is CₙH₂ₙ.error: CₙH₂ₙ is for cycloalkanes or alkenes, not straight-chain alkanes.
formula is CₙH₂ₙ.fix: Alkanes: CₙH₂ₙ₊₂. Each additional carbon adds CH₂, so formula gains 2H per C plus 2 extra.
formula is CₙH₂ₙ.action: Check: butane C₄H₁₀. Using formula: 2(4)+2 = 10 hydrogens. Correct.

all carbons have 3 bonds.error: All carbons in organic compounds form exactly 4 bonds.
all carbons have 3 bonds.fix: Carbon has 4 valence electrons, forms 4 covalent bonds. Terminal carbons bond to 3H and 1C.
all carbons have 3 bonds.action: Draw methane: 1 C bonded to 4 H. Draw ethane: each C bonds to 3H and 1C.

persistent.gap: You are confusing alkane properties with other hydrocarbon types.
persistent.action: Write molecular formulas for C1-C6 alkanes using CₙH₂ₙ₊₂. Verify each one.

cycloalkane_structures.name: Cycloalkane Structures
cycloalkane_structures.description: Cycloalkanes form closed rings with formula CₙH₂ₙ
cycloalkane_structures.correct: Cycloalkanes are ring-shaped alkanes. The ring formation removes 2 hydrogens compared to straight-chain alkanes, giving formula CₙH₂ₙ.

have formula CₙH₂ₙ₊₂.error: That formula is for straight-chain alkanes, not cycloalkanes.
have formula CₙH₂ₙ₊₂.fix: Ring formation uses 2 H that would otherwise be on terminal carbons. Formula: CₙH₂ₙ.
have formula CₙH₂ₙ₊₂.action: Cyclohexane: C₆H₁₂ = 2(6) = 12 H. Hexane: C₆H₁₄ = 2(6)+2 = 14 H.

contain double bonds.error: Cycloalkanes have only single bonds; the ring is not a double bond.
contain double bonds.fix: Cycloalkanes are saturated (all single bonds). The ring is formed by C-C single bonds.
contain double bonds.action: Draw cyclohexane as a hexagon. Each line is a single C-C bond, not a double bond.

are drawn as pentagons only.error: Cycloalkanes can have any ring size from 3 carbons upward.

persistent.gap: You do not understand how ring formation affects molecular formula.
persistent.action: Compare formulas: hexane vs cyclohexane, pentane vs cyclopentane. Note the 2H difference.

alkene_structures.name: Alkene Structures
alkene_structures.description: Alkenes contain at least one C=C double bond
alkene_structures.correct: Alkenes are unsaturated hydrocarbons with at least one carbon-carbon double bond. Their molecular formula is CₙH₂ₙ (for one double bond).

contain only single bonds.error: Alkenes must contain at least one C=C double bond.
contain only single bonds.fix: Alk-ENE = contains double bond. The -ene suffix indicates unsaturation.
contain only single bonds.action: Ethene has CH₂=CH₂. The double bond is the defining feature.

formula is CₙH₂ₙ₊₂.error: CₙH₂ₙ₊₂ is for saturated alkanes without double bonds.
formula is CₙH₂ₙ₊₂.fix: Each double bond removes 2 H from the saturated formula. One double bond: CₙH₂ₙ.
formula is CₙH₂ₙ₊₂.action: Propene: C₃H₆ = 2(3) = 6 H. Propane: C₃H₈ = 2(3)+2 = 8 H. Lost 2 H for double bond.

double bond can be anywhere.error: Double bond position affects naming and properties - it matters where it is.
double bond can be anywhere.fix: But-1-ene has double bond at position 1; but-2-ene at position 2. Different compounds.
double bond can be anywhere.action: Draw but-1-ene (CH₂=CHCH₂CH₃) and but-2-ene (CH₃CH=CHCH₃). Note the position difference.

persistent.gap: You are confusing alkene and alkane properties.
persistent.action: Draw ethene, propene, and but-1-ene. Show the double bond clearly in each.

benzene_structure.name: Benzene Structure
benzene_structure.description: Benzene is a cyclic aromatic hydrocarbon with alternating double bonds
benzene_structure.correct: Benzene (C₆H₆) has a planar hexagonal ring with delocalised electrons. It is drawn as a hexagon with either alternating double bonds or a circle inside.

has formula C₆H₁₂.fix: Benzene has 3 double bonds (removes 6 H from cyclohexane formula). Formula: C₆H₆.
has formula C₆H₁₂.action: Compare: cyclohexane C₆H₁₂ vs benzene C₆H₆. The difference reflects the double bonds.

has three separate double bonds.error: Benzene has delocalised electrons, not localised double bonds.
has three separate double bonds.fix: Electrons are shared across all 6 carbons equally. The circle notation represents this delocalisation.
has three separate double bonds.action: Draw benzene with a circle inside the hexagon to show electron delocalisation.

is the same as cyclohexene.error: Cyclohexene has one double bond; benzene has a delocalised aromatic ring.
is the same as cyclohexene.fix: Benzene is aromatic (special stability from delocalisation). Cyclohexene is just unsaturated.
is the same as cyclohexene.action: Cyclohexene C₆H₁₀: one double bond. Benzene C₆H₆: aromatic ring. Very different.

persistent.gap: You do not understand benzene's unique aromatic structure.
persistent.action: Draw benzene both ways: with alternating double bonds and with the circle. Understand they represent the same thing.

alcohol_classification.name: Alcohol Classification
alcohol_classification.description: Alcohols are classified as primary, secondary, or tertiary based on carbon substitution
alcohol_classification.correct: Primary alcohol: -OH on carbon bonded to 1 other carbon. Secondary: -OH on carbon bonded to 2 other carbons. Tertiary: -OH on carbon bonded to 3 other carbons.

based on position number.error: Classification is based on how many carbons attach to the -OH carbon, not position in chain.
based on position number.fix: Primary, secondary, tertiary refers to substitution pattern, not IUPAC numbering.
based on position number.action: Propan-2-ol is secondary (2 carbons attached to -OH carbon), not because of the '2' in the name.

tertiary has 3 OH groups.error: Tertiary refers to the carbon environment, not number of -OH groups.
tertiary has 3 OH groups.fix: Tertiary alcohol: the carbon bearing -OH is bonded to 3 other carbons. Still just 1 -OH.
tertiary has 3 OH groups.action: Draw 2-methylpropan-2-ol: central C has -OH and 3 methyl groups attached.

primary is always on carbon 1.error: Primary refers to substitution, not chain position.
primary is always on carbon 1.fix: 2-methylpropan-1-ol is primary (the -OH carbon bonds to only 1 other C), despite having substituents.
primary is always on carbon 1.action: Focus on the -OH carbon itself. Count how many other carbons directly bond to it.

persistent.gap: You are confusing alcohol classification with IUPAC numbering.
persistent.action: Draw and classify: ethanol, propan-1-ol, propan-2-ol, 2-methylpropan-2-ol.

carbonyl_distinction.name: Aldehyde vs Ketone Distinction
carbonyl_distinction.description: Aldehydes have the carbonyl at chain end; ketones have it mid-chain
carbonyl_distinction.correct: Aldehydes have the C=O group at a terminal carbon (bonded to H). Ketones have the C=O group on an internal carbon (bonded to two other carbons).

both have -CHO group.error: Only aldehydes have -CHO. Ketones have -CO- between carbons.
both have -CHO group.fix: Aldehyde ends in -CHO. Ketone has C=O with carbons on both sides, no H on carbonyl C.

ketones have OH group.error: Ketones have C=O, not C-OH. That would be an alcohol or carboxylic acid.
ketones have OH group.fix: Carbonyl = C=O (double bond to oxygen). Hydroxyl = C-O-H (single bond with H).
ketones have OH group.action: Draw propanone: the oxygen is double-bonded to carbon, no hydrogen on oxygen.

aldehydes are always larger.error: Size depends on carbon chain length, not functional group type.
aldehydes are always larger.fix: Methanal (1C) is smaller than propanone (3C). Size is about carbon count.
aldehydes are always larger.action: Ethanal has 2 carbons. Propanone has 3 carbons. The ketone is larger here.

persistent.gap: You are not distinguishing aldehyde and ketone functional groups.
persistent.action: Draw propanal and propanone side by side. Label the carbonyl position in each.

carboxylic_acid_structure.name: Carboxylic Acid Structure
carboxylic_acid_structure.description: Carboxylic acids have the -COOH functional group
carboxylic_acid_structure.correct: Carboxylic acids contain the carboxyl group (-COOH): a carbonyl (C=O) and hydroxyl (-OH) on the same carbon at the chain terminus.

have separate C=O and -OH.error: In carboxylic acids, C=O and -OH are on the same carbon, not separate.
have separate C=O and -OH.fix: The carboxyl group is -COOH: one carbon has both C=O and O-H attached.
have separate C=O and -OH.action: Draw ethanoic acid: CH₃COOH. The terminal carbon has double bond to O AND single bond to OH.

are the same as esters.error: Esters have -COO- linking two carbon groups; acids have -COOH with terminal H.
are the same as esters.fix: Carboxylic acid: R-COOH. Ester: R-COO-R'. The ester has no acidic hydrogen.
are the same as esters.action: Compare ethanoic acid (CH₃COOH) with methyl ethanoate (CH₃COOCH₃).

can occur mid-chain.error: The carboxyl group must be at the chain terminus.
can occur mid-chain.fix: By definition, -COOH is terminal. A mid-chain C=O with OH would be a different compound.
can occur mid-chain.action: Number carbons starting from -COOH. It is always carbon 1.

persistent.gap: You do not understand the structure of the carboxyl group.
persistent.action: Draw and label all bonds in propanoic acid: identify the C=O and O-H on the same carbon.

ester_structure.name: Ester Structure
ester_structure.description: Esters have -COO- linking a carbonyl carbon to an oxygen then another carbon
ester_structure.correct: Esters contain the ester linkage: -COO- where the carbonyl carbon bonds to oxygen, which then bonds to another carbon. No hydrogen on the ester oxygen.

have acidic hydrogen.error: Esters do not have a hydrogen on the ester oxygen like carboxylic acids do.
have acidic hydrogen.fix: Acid: R-COOH (H present). Ester: R-COO-R' (no H, another carbon instead).
have acidic hydrogen.action: Esters form when the H of -COOH is replaced by a carbon chain from an alcohol.

are named acid first.error: Esters are named with the alcohol-derived part first, then the acid-derived part.
are named acid first.fix: Methyl ethanoate: methyl (from methanol) + ethanoate (from ethanoic acid).
are named acid first.action: Name the alkyl group from alcohol first, then the -oate from the acid.

have two separate oxygens.error: The two oxygens are bonded to the same carbon in the ester linkage.
have two separate oxygens.fix: The ester carbon has C=O (double bond) and C-O-C (single bond to second carbon) from same C.
have two separate oxygens.action: Draw methyl ethanoate: CH₃-CO-O-CH₃. Both oxygens attach to the central carbonyl C.

persistent.gap: You are confusing ester structure with carboxylic acid structure.
persistent.action: Draw ethanoic acid and ethyl ethanoate. Circle the different oxygen environments.

amine_structure.name: Primary Amine Structure
amine_structure.description: Primary amines have the -NH₂ group bonded to a carbon
amine_structure.correct: Primary amines have nitrogen bonded to one carbon and two hydrogens: R-NH₂. The nitrogen carries a lone pair and can act as a base.

nitrogen bonded to two carbons.error: That would be a secondary amine, not primary.
nitrogen bonded to two carbons.fix: Primary: R-NH₂ (1 carbon on N). Secondary: R-NH-R' (2 carbons). Tertiary: R₃N (3 carbons).
nitrogen bonded to two carbons.action: Methylamine CH₃NH₂ is primary. Dimethylamine (CH₃)₂NH is secondary.

have no hydrogen on nitrogen.error: Primary amines have two hydrogens on nitrogen.
have no hydrogen on nitrogen.fix: Primary = 2 H on N. Secondary = 1 H on N. Tertiary = 0 H on N.
have no hydrogen on nitrogen.action: Draw propylamine: CH₃CH₂CH₂NH₂. The nitrogen has 2 H atoms.

are acidic like carboxylic acids.error: Amines are basic, not acidic. They accept protons.
are acidic like carboxylic acids.fix: The lone pair on nitrogen can accept H⁺, making amines bases, not acids.
are acidic like carboxylic acids.action: Amines turn red litmus blue (base), unlike carboxylic acids which are acidic.

persistent.gap: You are confusing amine classification or confusing amines with other functional groups.
persistent.action: Draw and label methylamine, ethylamine, and propylamine as primary amines.

amide_structure.name: Primary Amide Structure
amide_structure.description: Primary amides have nitrogen bonded to a carbonyl carbon and two hydrogens
amide_structure.correct: Primary amides have the structure R-CO-NH₂: a carbonyl group bonded directly to a nitrogen that carries two hydrogens.

same as amine.error: Amides have a carbonyl (C=O) attached to nitrogen; amines do not.
same as amine.fix: Amine: R-NH₂. Amide: R-CO-NH₂. The carbonyl makes a huge difference in properties.
same as amine.action: Compare ethanamine (amine) with ethanamide (amide). Note the C=O in the amide.

nitrogen has no hydrogens.error: Primary amides have two hydrogens on nitrogen.
nitrogen has no hydrogens.fix: Primary amide: -CONH₂. Secondary amide: -CONHR. Tertiary amide: -CONR₂.
nitrogen has no hydrogens.action: Draw propanamide: CH₃CH₂CONH₂. Two H atoms on the nitrogen.

carbonyl is separate from N.error: In amides, the carbonyl carbon is directly bonded to nitrogen.
carbonyl is separate from N.fix: The defining feature: C=O connected directly to N. This is the amide bond.
carbonyl is separate from N.action: Draw the amide linkage: -C(=O)-N<. The C=O and N are directly connected.

persistent.gap: You are confusing amides with amines or not recognising the amide linkage.
persistent.action: Draw ethanamide and label: carbonyl (C=O), nitrogen (N), and the two hydrogens on N.

haloalkane_structure.name: Haloalkane Structure
haloalkane_structure.description: Haloalkanes have halogen atoms (F, Cl, Br, I) replacing hydrogen
haloalkane_structure.correct: Haloalkanes are alkanes with one or more hydrogen atoms replaced by halogen atoms. The halogen is named as a prefix: fluoro-, chloro-, bromo-, iodo-.

halogens are separate molecules.error: The halogen is covalently bonded to a carbon in the alkane chain.
halogens are separate molecules.fix: R-X where X is F, Cl, Br, or I bonded directly to carbon.
halogens are separate molecules.action: Chloromethane: CH₃Cl. The Cl is part of the molecule, not separate.

naming uses -ide suffix.error: Halogens in organic compounds use prefix naming, not -ide suffix.
naming uses -ide suffix.fix: -ide is for ions (chloride). Prefix naming for organic: chloro-, bromo-, etc.

can only have one halogen.error: Molecules can have multiple halogen atoms.
can only have one halogen.fix: Dichloromethane (CH₂Cl₂), trichloromethane (CHCl₃), etc. Multiple halogens are common.
can only have one halogen.action: Draw 1,2-dichloroethane: both carbons have a chlorine attached.

persistent.gap: You do not understand haloalkane naming or structure.

formula_types.title: Types of Organic Formulas
formula_types.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of the four main types of organic formulas.

sentences.text: The {{d1}} shows only the types and numbers of atoms in a molecule, with carbon listed {{d2}}, followed by hydrogen, then other elements alphabetically.

d1.tooltip: Which formula type lists only atom counts without showing bonds?

d2.tooltip: In organic chemistry, which element is listed before hydrogen?

sentences.text: The {{d3}} explicitly shows all atoms and all bonds, using lines to represent {{d4}} bonds between atoms.

d3.tooltip: Which formula shows every atom symbol and every bond line?

d4.tooltip: Organic molecules contain what type of bonding between atoms?

sentences.text: The {{d5}} groups atoms together and typically {{d6}} the bond lines between atoms, making it more compact than the structural formula.

d5.tooltip: Which formula uses groups like CH₃ and CH₂ without showing all bonds?

d6.tooltip: What happens to the individual bond lines in a condensed formula?

sentences.text: A limitation of molecular formulas is that they cannot distinguish between {{d7}}, which are compounds with the same molecular formula but different {{d8}}.

d7.tooltip: What do we call compounds with identical formulas but different structures?

d8.tooltip: Isomers differ in how their atoms are connected.

skeletal_formulas.title: Understanding Skeletal Formulas
skeletal_formulas.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to show your understanding of skeletal formula conventions.

sentences.text: In skeletal formulas, hydrocarbon chains are represented by {{d1}} lines, where each vertex and endpoint represents a {{d2}} atom.

d1.tooltip: What pattern do carbon chains follow in skeletal formulas?

d2.tooltip: Which atom is found at every corner and end of the zigzag?

sentences.text: In skeletal formulas, {{d3}} atoms bonded to carbon are not drawn because each carbon is assumed to have enough bonds to satisfy its {{d4}} of four.

d3.tooltip: Which element is typically hidden when bonded to carbon?

d4.tooltip: Carbon forms exactly four bonds to satisfy what requirement?

sentences.text: All atoms except carbon and {{d5}} bonded to carbon must be shown with their chemical symbols, including elements like O, N, and the {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: Which two elements can be hidden in skeletal formulas?

d6.tooltip: F, Cl, Br, and I belong to which group that must be shown?

sentences.text: Hydrogen atoms bonded to {{d7}} must always be shown in skeletal formulas, such as the H in an -OH group or -NH₂ group.

d7.tooltip: The term for atoms other than carbon and hydrogen in organic molecules.

hydrocarbons.title: Hydrocarbon Structures
hydrocarbons.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of alkane, alkene, and benzene structures.

sentences.text: Alkanes are {{d1}} hydrocarbons containing only single bonds, with the molecular formula {{d2}} for straight-chain compounds.

d1.tooltip: A hydrocarbon with only single bonds is described as what?

d2.tooltip: What is the general formula for straight-chain alkanes?

sentences.text: Cycloalkanes form closed {{d3}} structures and have the molecular formula {{d4}}, which has two fewer hydrogens than the corresponding straight-chain alkane.

d3.tooltip: What shape do cycloalkane carbon chains form?

d4.tooltip: Ring formation removes 2 H. What formula results?

sentences.text: Alkenes contain at least one carbon-carbon {{d5}} bond and are classified as {{d6}} hydrocarbons.

d5.tooltip: The -ene suffix indicates what type of C-C bond?

d6.tooltip: Hydrocarbons with double bonds are described as what?

sentences.text: Benzene has the molecular formula {{d7}} and features a hexagonal ring with {{d8}} electrons shared across all six carbon atoms.

d7.tooltip: Benzene has 6 carbons. How many hydrogens does it have?

d8.tooltip: Electrons shared across the whole ring are described as what?

functional_groups.title: Functional Group Structures
functional_groups.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of common functional groups.

sentences.text: Alcohols contain the hydroxyl group (-OH) and are classified as primary, secondary, or tertiary based on how many {{d1}} are bonded to the carbon bearing the -OH group.

d1.tooltip: Alcohol classification depends on substitution at which carbon?

sentences.text: Aldehydes have the carbonyl group (C=O) at the {{d2}} of the carbon chain, while ketones have the carbonyl group on an {{d3}} carbon.

d2.tooltip: Where must the carbonyl be located in an aldehyde?

d3.tooltip: The ketone carbonyl carbon is bonded to carbons on both sides.

sentences.text: Carboxylic acids contain the {{d4}} group (-COOH), which combines a carbonyl and a hydroxyl group on the same terminal carbon.

d4.tooltip: What is the name of the -COOH functional group?

sentences.text: Esters have the structure R-COO-R' where the oxygen between the two carbon groups comes from the {{d5}} during esterification.

d5.tooltip: In esterification, which reactant provides the single-bonded oxygen?

sentences.text: Primary amines have the general structure R-NH₂, where the nitrogen is bonded to {{d6}} carbon and two hydrogen atoms.

d6.tooltip: How many carbon atoms bond to nitrogen in a primary amine?

sentences.text: Primary amides have the structure R-CO-NH₂, containing a {{d7}} group directly bonded to a nitrogen carrying two hydrogens.

d7.tooltip: What type of C=O group is bonded to nitrogen in an amide?

sentences.text: Haloalkanes are alkanes where one or more hydrogen atoms have been replaced by {{d8}} atoms such as F, Cl, Br, or I.

d8.tooltip: Which group of elements (Group 17) replace hydrogen in haloalkanes?

formula_types.title: Applying Formula Representations
formula_types.instructions: Apply your understanding to identify and compare formula types.

sentences.text: When CH₃CH₂OH and CH₃OCH₃ both have the molecular formula C₂H₆O, the molecular formula alone {{d1}} distinguish between them, demonstrating why {{d2}} formulas are needed.

d1.tooltip: Can molecular formula tell isomers apart?

d2.tooltip: Which formula type shows how atoms are connected?

sentences.text: The semi-structural formula CH₃(CH₂)₄CH₃ uses brackets to indicate {{d3}} repeating CH₂ units, representing the compound {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: Count: hexane has 6 carbons. Two are CH₃, how many are CH₂?

d4.tooltip: CH₃ + 4×CH₂ + CH₃ = how many carbons total?

sentences.text: In the semi-structural formula CH₃CH(CH₃)CH₂CH₃, the brackets around CH₃ indicate a {{d5}} group attached to the second carbon of the main chain, making this {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: Brackets after a carbon in the main chain indicate what?

d6.tooltip: Count the main chain (4C) and identify the branch position.

sentences.text: Drawing a structural formula requires showing every {{d7}}, which becomes tedious for larger molecules, whereas skeletal formulas hide {{d8}} to simplify the representation.

d8.tooltip: Which two elements are typically omitted in skeletal formulas?

skeletal_formulas.title: Reading and Drawing Skeletal Formulas
skeletal_formulas.instructions: Apply your understanding to interpret and construct skeletal formulas.

sentences.text: A skeletal formula showing a zigzag with 5 vertices (including endpoints) represents an alkane with {{d1}} carbon atoms and molecular formula {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Each vertex plus each endpoint = one carbon.

sentences.text: When drawing an alcohol in skeletal form, the {{d3}} must be written explicitly, including the hydrogen atom that makes it different from an {{d4}} linkage.

d3.tooltip: The hydroxyl group must be shown because O is a heteroatom.

d4.tooltip: An -O- between two carbons without H is called what?

sentences.text: In skeletal formulas, a carbon at a {{d5}} of the zigzag is shown to have only 2 bonds visible, but is assumed to also bond to {{d6}} hydrogen atoms.

d5.tooltip: Where lines change direction in the zigzag.

d6.tooltip: Carbon needs 4 bonds. 2 visible C-C bonds means how many invisible C-H?

sentences.text: When a skeletal formula shows a line extending from a vertex, this represents a {{d7}}, adding one carbon to the total count.

d7.tooltip: A line going away from the main chain indicates what?

hydrocarbons.title: Comparing Hydrocarbon Types
hydrocarbons.instructions: Compare the structures of different hydrocarbon classes.

sentences.text: Hexane (C₆H₁₄) has {{d1}} more hydrogen atoms than cyclohexane (C₆H₁₂) because the ring formation eliminates the need for {{d2}} terminal hydrogens.

d1.tooltip: Compare C₆H₁₄ with C₆H₁₂. What is the difference?

d2.tooltip: The ring closes, removing H from what would be the chain ends.

sentences.text: The presence of a C=C double bond in propene means it has the molecular formula {{d3}}, which is {{d4}} fewer than propane.

d3.tooltip: Use CₙH₂ₙ for alkenes with one double bond.

d4.tooltip: Each double bond removes how many H compared to an alkane?

sentences.text: Benzene is drawn with a circle inside a hexagon to represent the {{d5}} of electrons, which gives it special stability called {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: The electrons are not fixed in one position but spread around the ring.

d6.tooltip: The special stability of benzene-like rings has a specific name.

sentences.text: Unlike cyclohexane, benzene has only {{d7}} hydrogen atoms because each carbon in the ring is involved in {{d8}} bonds total.

d7.tooltip: C₆H₆ means how many H atoms?

d8.tooltip: Each carbon bonds to 2 other C (one double equivalent) and 1 H.

functional_groups.title: Comparing Functional Group Structures
functional_groups.instructions: Apply your understanding to distinguish between related functional groups.

sentences.text: Propan-2-ol is classified as a {{d1}} alcohol because the carbon bonded to -OH is attached to {{d2}} other carbon atoms.

d1.tooltip: Count carbons attached to the carbon bearing -OH.

d2.tooltip: In propan-2-ol, the central carbon has CH₃ groups on each side.

sentences.text: The key difference between propanal (an aldehyde) and propanone (a ketone) is that propanal has a {{d3}} on the carbonyl carbon, while propanone has {{d4}} on both sides.

d3.tooltip: Aldehydes have -CHO: what is bonded to the carbonyl carbon?

d4.tooltip: Ketones have the carbonyl surrounded by C on both sides.

sentences.text: When ethanoic acid reacts with methanol to form an ester, the product is named {{d5}}, and the {{d6}} is lost as water.

d5.tooltip: Alcohol part (methyl) comes first, then acid part (-oate).

d6.correct: -OH from acid and H from alcohol
distractors: -OH from alcohol and H from acid
d6.tooltip: The -OH from the acid and the H from the alcohol form H₂O.

sentences.text: The difference between an amine and an amide is that an amide contains a {{d7}} group bonded directly to the nitrogen, which significantly affects its {{d8}}.

d7.tooltip: What functional group (C=O) is attached to N in amides?

d8.tooltip: The carbonyl reduces the electron density on N, affecting what property?

formula_types.title: Mastering Formula Conversions
formula_types.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of formula types and their interconversion.

sentences.text: The molecular formula C₃H₆O could represent several different compounds including an {{d1}} or a {{d2}}, which demonstrates why this formula type alone is insufficient for identification.

d1.tooltip: Propanal (C₃H₆O) is what type of compound?

d2.tooltip: Propanone (C₃H₆O) is what type of compound?

sentences.text: Converting from skeletal to molecular formula requires counting {{d3}} at vertices and endpoints, then calculating hydrogen using the formula {{d4}} for saturated compounds.

d3.tooltip: What element is represented at every corner and end?

d4.tooltip: The general formula for saturated, acyclic hydrocarbons.

sentences.text: The semi-structural formula CH₃CH(OH)CH₃ represents {{d5}}, where the brackets indicate that the -OH group is attached to the {{d6}} carbon.

d5.tooltip: 3 carbons with -OH on the middle one is named what?

d6.tooltip: The bracket appears after the second carbon in the chain.

sentences.text: When comparing formulas, the structural formula provides the most {{d7}}, while the skeletal formula provides the most {{d8}} representation.

d7.tooltip: Showing every atom and bond gives maximum what?

d8.tooltip: Hiding C and H makes the formula more what?

skeletal_formulas.title: Advanced Skeletal Formula Interpretation
skeletal_formulas.instructions: Demonstrate mastery of skeletal formula reading and construction.

sentences.text: A skeletal formula showing a hexagon with a circle inside and an -OH attached to one vertex represents {{d1}}, which is an example of an {{d2}} compound.

d2.tooltip: Compounds containing a benzene ring are classified as what?

sentences.text: In the skeletal formula of 2-methylbutane, the main chain has {{d3}} vertices and there is a branch at the {{d4}} vertex from the left.

d3.tooltip: Butane main chain has how many carbons?

d4.tooltip: The '2-' in 2-methylbutane indicates branch at which position?

sentences.text: When skeletal formulas show a double line between two vertices, this represents a {{d5}}, which means those carbons have {{d6}} hydrogen atoms attached than they would in an alkane.

d5.tooltip: Two parallel lines between atoms indicate what bond type?

d6.tooltip: Double bonded carbons use more valence for C-C bonding, leaving less for H.

sentences.text: The skeletal formula for ethyl ethanoate shows a zigzag with an {{d7}} in the middle, representing the {{d8}} linkage connecting the acid and alcohol portions.

d7.tooltip: The ester functional group is written as what in the middle?

d8.tooltip: The -COO- group linking two carbon chains is the defining feature of what?

hydrocarbons.title: Synthesis and Analysis of Hydrocarbon Formulas
hydrocarbons.instructions: Demonstrate complete mastery of hydrocarbon formula relationships.

sentences.text: Converting cyclohexane to benzene involves removing {{d1}} hydrogen atoms and introducing {{d2}} in the ring structure.

d1.tooltip: C₆H₁₂ → C₆H₆. How many H removed?

d2.tooltip: What structural feature replaces the removed hydrogens?

sentences.text: The fact that cyclohexane (C₆H₁₂) and hex-1-ene (C₆H₁₂) share the same {{d3}} but have different structures makes them {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: Both have identical atom counts but different arrangements.

d4.tooltip: Compounds with same formula but different structures are called what?

sentences.text: In the homologous series of alkanes, each member differs from the next by a {{d5}} unit, which adds {{d6}} to the molecular mass.

d5.tooltip: What group is added going from one alkane to the next?

d6.tooltip: C = 12, H = 1. What is the mass of CH₂?

sentences.text: When determining the degree of unsaturation from formula C₅H₈, we compare to the saturated formula C₅H₁₂, finding {{d7}} hydrogen deficiency, indicating {{d8}} of unsaturation.

d8.tooltip: Each degree of unsaturation accounts for 2 missing H.

functional_groups.title: Integrating Functional Group Knowledge
functional_groups.instructions: Demonstrate mastery by connecting functional group structures to their representations.

sentences.text: A compound with molecular formula C₄H₁₀O that gives a {{d1}} chemical test and is classified as {{d2}} must have the structure (CH₃)₃COH.

d1.tooltip: Tertiary alcohols do not react with oxidising agents.

d2.tooltip: The -OH carbon is bonded to 3 other carbons.

sentences.text: The functional group -CONH₂ is found in primary amides and differs from -COOH in that the {{d3}} has been replaced by {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: What part of the carboxylic acid is changed?

d4.tooltip: What replaces the -OH of the acid?

sentences.text: In IUPAC naming, the position of a halogen in a haloalkane is indicated by a {{d5}}, and the halogen name uses the prefix {{d6}} for bromine.

d5.tooltip: How is the halogen position indicated in the name?

d6.tooltip: What prefix is used for Br in organic naming?

sentences.text: The structural formula of propyl methanoate shows a {{d7}} group from methanoic acid connected through an oxygen to a {{d8}} chain from propanol.

d7.tooltip: Methanoic acid contributes what group (minus OH) to the ester?

d8.tooltip: Propyl indicates how many carbons from the alcohol?
